awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Skills, Majors, and Jobs: Does Higher Education Respond?
awd_abstract_narration:
Rapid technical progress leads to skill obsolescence, yet educational institutions and students are slow to respond to these changes in the labor market.  This research project will use a large data set on changes in skill demand and college enrolments by major and the content of majors to investigate two interrelated questions: (i) what skills are associated with each college major and how does skill demand vary over time and space? (ii) how do higher education course-offerings and student course-taking respond to changes in demand for skills? The research will be based on data on all job postings over a time matched with data on all course offering (and their content) in a state.  The results can help institutions respond to skill demand by rapidly changing the content of their curricula and educational policy makers plan better.  The results will also help guide students not only in their choice of majors but also the courses and skills they choose to acquire in their chosen majors.  By providing inputs into policies that align skill needs and skill training in a rapidly changing technological work place, this research will help US educational institutions provide the skills the economy needs, hence lead to rapid economic growth and improved well-being of Americans.

This project will use merged data from the Burning Glass project and the Delaware Cost Project which has department level panel data on credits, courses and faculty as well as individual level data on student course taking, quasi-experimental methods and machine learning techniques to investigate how college students and college administration respond to changes in labor skill demand.  Specifically, it investigates what skills are associated with each college major, how within major cross-major skills demand differ across space and through time, and how skill investment responds to changes in skill demand in the labor market.  Previous studies have focused on the demand side of skill acquisition; this project will however look at how skill supply (by university providers and students) respond to changes in skill demand by exploring several aspects university curriculum that makes these supply responses possible.   The quasi-experimental methods permit causal identification of the effect of changes in skill demand on human capital investment. The project will explore differential responses at lower-division, upper-division, and graduate levels.  The results of this research will provide guidance on policies to align skill investment to changes in skill demand and in so doing will provide the needed skills and lead to faster economic growth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project had two main goals. First, we sought to provide a rich description of the link between majors, skills, and jobs using machine-learning techniques and the near universe of all online job ads in the US over the past decade. Specifically, we asked (RQ1) What general and specific skills are associated, in practice, with each college major? and (RQ2) How does across- and within-major skill demand vary over time, space, and with other characteristics? Second, we aimed to quantify how skill accumulation (via postsecondary educational investment) responds to changes in local skill demand and what individual and institutional factors might affect this response. That is, (RQ3) How does higher education investment respond to these changes in the demand for skills?

In addressing these questions, the research team produced three manuscripts, two of which were published as journal articles and the third under revision at the time of this report; additionally, a fourth manuscript was still under preparation. Furthermore, by this time members of the research team presented findings from one or more of the manuscripts approximately 30 times at invited seminars and academic and policy conferences. This includes a joint research-practitioner one-day conference organized by the co-PIs and held in Ann Arbor in October 2023; more than 50 people attended, with presentations by both the research team and external researchers, as well as on current and emerging methods on the use of labor market data to influence course offerings and selection.

The specific findings of the project are extensive and have considerable intellectual merit. Our descriptive analysis manuscript (addressing RQ1 and RQ2 and published in Labour Economics, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.labeco.2023.102429) documents the skill content of college majors as perceived by employers and expressed in the near universe of online job ads. We find that certain skills––such as social and organizational skills––are sought by employers of almost all college majors. Other skills, such as customer service, are associated with fewer majors. Nursing and education, which are associated with these latter skills, are thus more specialized. Employers in high-wage metro areas demand more of most types of skills in generalist majors such as business. However, the cross-area variation in skill demand within a given major is only weakly correlated with major-specific earnings across areas. This suggests that one can reasonably conceptualize majors as portable bundles of skills. (This is not the case with occupations.)

Our analysis of the labor markets served by colleges across the United States, toward addressing RQ2 and RQ3 (and published in Journal of Policy Analysis and Management, https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/pam.22553), finds that the geographic dispersion of alumni is more than twice as great for highly selective 4-year institutions as for 2-year institutions. However, more than one-quarter of 2-year institutions disperse alumni more diversely than the average public 4-year institution. In an application of these data, we find that the average strength of the labor market to which a college sends its graduates predicts college-specific intergenerational economic mobility.  Mobility also affects the public return on investment in postsecondary institutions by states, with regional public universities tending to have the highest number of local graduates produced and kept per public dollar invested.

Our manuscript on assigning college majors to individual job ads (still underway) makes a methodological contribution by showing sizable performance and accuracy gains from using  random forests, rich job ad information (e.g., skill and other text listed in the ad), and a LRAP maximization criterion relative to more conventional approaches (standard logit), basic job ad information (e.g., occupation and industry), and single-major classification functions. Using our classification scheme to impute majors over all ads, including those that do not specifically mention a college major, alters measured labor demand, especially for majors whose skills are widely applicable to many occupations.

Finally, our causal analysis (RQ3) finds that postsecondary institutions and students are quite responsive to shifts in major-specific labor demand. We find that a 1 percent greater shift in job ads in a given major leads to a 1.3 percent greater increase in bachelor’s degree production and of credits taken in that major. Response magnitudes are greater for less selective institutions and those more focused on teaching than research. Changes in non-tenure-track faculty allocations and the credits they teach partially mediate this overall response.

The project has already begun to have broader impacts. Beyond academic audiences and the conferences mentioned earlier, co-PIs had conversations with policymakers in three states (OK, SC, and VA) regarding our findings and implications for higher education funding and course requirements. The research also received considerable news coverage, ranging from data blogs to leading mainstream national newspapers and public radio. Additionally, we have shared our dataset on the markets served by each U.S. college via Open ICPSR: https://www.openicpsr.org/openicpsr/project/170381/version/V3/view. As of November 29, 2023, the archive had 4799 views and 374 downloads.
